Introduction

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a histopathologic pattern of glomerular injury with a wide range of clinical manifestations, including nephrotic syndrome (heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema), nephritic syndrome (hematuria, hypertension, renal dysfunction), or mixed nephrotic-nephritic syndrome.  Historically categorized into types I, II, and III based on electron microscopy findings, MPGN's contemporary classification emphasizes etiology, distinguishing between immune complex–mediated and complement-mediated MPGN.

Etiologies and pathophysiology



MPGN accounts for roughly 5%-10% of biopsy-confirmed glomerulonephritis cases.  It can arise from 2 distinct pathways:  immune complex deposition or dysregulated complement activation.

Immune complex–mediated MPGN



MPGN mediated by immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) constitutes 70%-80% of cases, predominantly affecting adolescents and young adults.  It is associated with:



  • Chronic infection:  Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is the most common cause; the mechanism involves cryoglobulin formation (discussed in a separate article).  Additional causes include hepatitis B virus (HBV) and endocarditis.
  • Autoimmune disease:  Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and Sjögren syndrome are commonly implicated.
  • Monoclonal gammopathy:  Etiologies involve IgM or IgG paraproteins, such as in multiple myeloma.


The pathophysiology of immune complex–mediated MPGN involves the deposition of antigen-antibody immune complexes in the subendothelial or mesangial spaces, which are readily accessible to renal circulation.  The subepithelial space is usually spared because it is located on the opposite side of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), through which immune complexes are too large to cross.  Immune complexes activate the classical complement pathway, which triggers inflammation and subsequent glomerular injury.

Complement-mediated MPGN



Complement-mediated MPGN, comprising 20%-30% of cases, often presents earlier in life due to its association with genetic mutations or acquired factors (eg, C3 nephritic factor autoantibodies) that dysregulate the alternative complement pathway.  The most common forms are C3 glomerulonephritis and dense-deposit disease.



Glomerular inflammation and damage in complement-mediated MPGN are similar to those of immune-complex disease.  However, complement-mediated MPGN results from unregulated complement activation, resulting in prominent C3 deposition in the GBM without significant immunoglobulin involvement.

Clinical and laboratory findings

Mixed nephrotic-nephritic pattern



MPGN most commonly presents as mixed nephrotic-nephritic syndrome (

figure 1
):



  • Nephrotic features:  Heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, and edema.
  • Nephritic features:  Hematuria (often macroscopic) with dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs) and casts, hypertension, and acute kidney injury.


Cryoglobulinemia-associated MPGN (eg, from HCV) may additionally involve vasculitis signs (eg, palpable purpura, neuropathy).  Complement-mediated MPGN may present with drusen (eye involvement) or atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome.

Hypocomplementemia



Low serum complement levels are frequently observed in all forms of MPGN, although the pattern can differ:



  • Immune complex–mediated MPGN:  Typically activates the classical pathway, reflected by a normal or mildly reduced C3 with low C4.
  • Complement-mediated MPGN:  Involves alternative pathway activation, causing decreased C3 with normal C4.  However, a normal C3 level does not exclude disease.

Diagnosis

Renal biopsy



Microscopic examination shows a characteristic pattern of glomerular injury (

image 1
):



  • Light microscopy:  Shows large, lobular glomeruli that are hypercellular due to the proliferation of mesangial cells, endothelial cells, and leukocytes.  Immune complex deposition results in thickened capillary walls, as well as the synthesis of new basement membrane material, which imparts a split (ie, tram track) appearance seen with special stains.
  • Immunofluorescence:  Reveals a granular pattern of IgG and C3 deposition within the capillary walls and mesangium.
  • Electron microscopy:  Shows subendothelial (ie, between the GBM and endothelium) and mesangial deposits.

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory evaluation includes the following:



  • Urinalysis:  Proteinuria and hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs or casts are hallmark findings.  Proteinuria can be quantified via 24-hour urine collection or urine protein/creatinine ratio.
  • Basic metabolic panel:  Elevated serum creatinine is common.
  • Serum albumin and lipid panel:  Hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia reflect a nephrotic component.
  • Serum complement and cryoglobulins:  Low C3 and C4 suggest immune complex–mediated MPGN (eg, cryoglobulinemia, SLE); cryoglobulins may be present.  Low C3 with normal C4 suggests complement-mediated MPGN; cryoglobulins are absent.
  • Infection serology:  Testing should include antibodies for HCV, HBV, and HIV.
  • Autoantibodies:  Positive antinuclear antibodies and anti–double stranded DNA antibodies suggest SLE.
  • Monoclonal gammopathy screening:  Serum protein electrophoresis, immunofixation, and free light-chain assay should be performed, particularly in older patients.


In patients with suspected complement-mediated disease, further testing (eg, C3 nephritic factor, genetic testing) should be pursued.

Management



General management measures include renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibition (eg, ACE inhibitors) to minimize proteinuria and control blood pressure, diuretics for volume overload, dietary sodium and protein restriction, and treatment of hyperlipidemia.

Immune complex–mediated MPGN



Management of immune complex–mediated disease involves addressing the underlying cause:



  • Infection:  Direct-acting antivirals should be administered for HCV-associated cases.  Antibiotics are indicated for bacterial causes (eg, endocarditis).  Immunosuppression should generally be avoided, except in certain cases (eg, severe cryoglobulinemia).
  • Autoimmune:  Immunosuppression (eg, corticosteroids, mycophenolate) is first-line treatment, such as in class IV lupus nephritis.
  • Monoclonal gammopathy:  The underlying hematologic disorder should be treated.

Complement-mediated MPGN



Optimal treatment of complement-mediated disease is less clear.  Initial treatment involves immunosuppressants, with complement inhibitors (eg, eculizumab) used in refractory cases.  Plasma infusion may occasionally be beneficial, especially for genetic complement factor deficiencies.

Summary



Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a histopathologic pattern of glomerular injury.  Modern classification emphasizes etiology, dividing the condition into 2 subtypes:  immune complex–mediated (70%-80% of cases) and complement-mediated (20%-30%).  Immune complex–mediated MPGN stems from chronic infections (eg, hepatitis C), autoimmune diseases (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus), or monoclonal gammopathies, with classical complement pathway activation (low C3 and C4).  Complement-mediated MPGN arises from alternative pathway dysregulation due to genetic mutations or autoantibodies causing isolated C3 reduction.



Diagnosis hinges on renal biopsy:  Immune complex cases show IgG/C3 deposits and subendothelial/mesangial deposits on electron microscopy, whereas complement-mediated cases exhibit C3-dominant immunofluorescence and/or intramembranous/dense deposits.  Laboratory evaluation focuses on complement testing, infectious/autoimmune serologies, and monoclonal protein screening.  Management targets underlying triggers (eg, with antivirals) in immune complex–mediated disease and uses immunosuppressants or complement inhibitors (eg, eculizumab) for complement-mediated cases.
